p.style: margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0in; hyphenation-ladder-count: no-limit; font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; hyphenate: false; hyphenation-remain-char-count: 2; hyphenation-push-char-count: 2; text-align: end;

margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0in; text-align: start; hyphenation-ladder-count: no-limit; font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; hyphenate: false; hyphenation-remain-char-count: 2; hyphenation-push-char-count: 2;

div.p:
During the holidays, dear Mr Holtze, I finished the examination of some Myrtaceae. So I let you now know, that 1201 and 1210 are Eugenia suborbicularis, Benth furthermore it seems, that 1203
For nos 1210 and 1203. see M to M. Holtze, list, 1891. haven't found 1201 on a list.
is only a variety of the same species, altho the fruit is of different size and taste. My working on your and other plants has been much retarded by the disturbances in the Department, involving the reduction of the working vote from £1600 to £400. From the enclosed print
Publication not identified. you can name all others of your Eugenias there, unless a second species with large fruits can be distinguished. Perhaps you may yet discover there also E. grandis, which is allied to E. suborbicularis. I presume you have the "Flora Australiensis" there, so that you can read the respective descriptions. A good full note on Eugenia suborbicularis fruit I could publish in the Gardeners Chronicle
is this published?
as from you. Cultivation would likely improve the fruit.

p.style: margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0in; text-align: start; hyphenation-ladder-count: no-limit; font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; hyphenate: false; hyphenation-remain-char-count: 2; hyphenation-push-char-count: 2;

div.p:
Let me thank you for the sending of your local Journal.
something from — Northern standard (1873-1955), Northern Territory times (1873-1932), North Australian and Northern Territory Goverenment gazette ?
Such an acknowledgment, as this, concerning Panicum spectabile, would do my Department always good. If the "Coapim" will grow in desert-sandhills, a whole revolution for the better will take place in all pastoral tracts of the Desert.
In the 1895 edition of Select extra-tropical plants (B95.08.04), M noted under Panicum spectabile: 'From Port Darwin largely distributed by the Messrs. Holtze'. I hope you will give roots to all desert-runs near you. I verely believe, that even Rabbits will not eat it out in sand. Urge your kind brother
Waldemar Holtze. to follow up collecting well, as his is an almost new district for plants. As he is not very far from the locality, at which Prof Stirling got the Marsupial Mole, could your brother try to get through the natives 1 or 2 for me at a fair payment?
M wanted this for the Stuttgart Museum.
Find letter to cross reference
Perhaps you could send him a little preserving material
